body_text.text: Bivalve is an important source of human dietary animal protein (Tan et al., 2019ab; Tan and Ransangan, 2016ab) , of which it accounted for about 15% of the average per capita animal protein for 1.5 billion people (FAO, 2018) . Mollusc aquaculture production represents 21.42% of total aquaculture production, with China accounting for 92.27% of total mollusc aquaculture production (FAO, 2018) . Bivalves play an important ecological role in aquatic environment, including habitat creation (Ekstrom et al., 2015; Coen et al., 2007) , suspension organic waste filtration and shoreline protection (Coen et al., 2007) . In addition, with the present of abundant filter-feeding bivalves, it can effectively control the abundance of many harmful algal species that are lethal to variety of marine organisms (Tan and Ransangan, 2015; Cerrato et al., 2004 ).

Global atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) levels have increased from about 280 ppm at Pre-industrial to about 400 ppm today (Queiros et al., 2015) . The increasing levels of CO 2 in the atmosphere trap more and more heat, warming the atmosphere and the ocean. The IPCC, (2014) revealed that the global average temperature of seawater has risen by at least 0.7 ˚C over the two and a half centuries.

At the same time, the increase in atmospheric CO 2 has caused dissolution of 550 billion tons of atmospheric CO 2 in global oceans, resulting in an increase of ocean acidity (pH is reduced from 8.2 to 8.1) in a process known as ocean acidification (OA) ( Figure 1 ) (Sabine et al. 2011; Feely et al., 2009) . It is predicted that by the end of the 21 st century, the pH of the ocean will decrease by 0.32 units (Queiros et al., 2015) , as a result, OA is considered to be one of the greatest threats to marine ecosystems in the near future (Halpern et al., 2008) Repeated episodes of bivalve massive mortalities (Tan and Zheng, 2019; Tan and Ransangan, 2019; Tan and Ransangan, 2016c; McFarland et al., 2016) , deadly bivalve disease outbreaks (Asplund et al., 2014; Williams et al., 2014) , growth and development retardations (Watson et al., 2009) , bivalve shell dissolutions (Yang et al., 2017; Waldbusser et al., 2010) and bivalve byssus strength reductions (Zhao et al., 2017; O'Donnell et al., 2013) , which involved all life stages of bivalve from larvae to juvenile and adults, have been reported worldwide. It is clear from the literature that the ocean warming and ocean acidification are the two main drivers of anthropogenic climate change and have deleterious effects on marine biological processes. In general, ocean warming has received a lot of attention in the aquaculture sector, but acidification has received relatively less attention. Recently, the effects of seawater warming on bivalve aquaculture have been reviewed by Tan and Zheng (2019) . On the other hand, for OA, although there are many time series observations and climate stimulation experiments on the effects of OA on bivalves, the information is not organized. Therefore, a rigorous scientific review is needed to summarize and interpret the impact of OA on bivalve aquaculture. This information will aid in establishing aquaculture and fishery management plans to be implemented in both commercial fisheries and nature conservations. To the best of our knowledge, this article represents the first review that summarizes the potential impacts of OA on bivalve aquaculture based on available scientific evidence and to discuss the future direction of bivalve farming.

In the past 23 million years, the concentration of atmospheric CO has remained in the range of 140 to 280 ppm, and the surface ocean pH has remained consistent from pH 8.1 to 8.3 (Pearson and Palmer, 2000) . However, since the beginning of the industrial revolution in the past 200 years, CO 2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion and deforestation have led to a dramatic increase in atmospheric CO 2 concentrations from 280 ppm to 380 ppm (TansNOAA/ESRLrecords). In order to meet the new equilibrium of carbon, some atmospheric CO 2 (about 550 billion tons of atmospheric CO 2 ) is dissolved in the world's oceans, changing seawater carbon chemistry and acidifying the oceans (Doney et al., 2009) . To date, ocean pH has been reduced by 0.1 units with an increase in acidity (H + ) of about 30% (Feely et al., 2009) . It is predicted that the ocean pH will be further reduced by approximately 0.32 units in 2100, and this pH reduction is equivalent to a 150% increase in ocean acidity (IPCC, 2007) . According to climate model projections, Queiros et al. (2015) and Gattuso and Hansson (2011) predicted that the ocean pH will reach pH 7.4 by 2300. Higherlatitude systems typically have low buffering capacity to resist acidity changes, therefore, OA has a greater impact on high latitude temperate waters than in tropical waters (Lough and Hobday, 2011; IPCC, 2007) . In fact, multiple lines of evidence have confirmed a significant pH drop in the North Atlantic and North Pacific oceans (Thornalley et al., 2018; Levin, 2018; Brennan et al., 2016; Gilbert et al., 2005) .

Based on the climate change model, Feely et al. (2009) predicted that OA may last for hundreds of years. The steady increase in dissolution of atmospheric CO 2 in the upper water column have increased the prevalence of aragonite saturation (Ω ar ) < 1 in the water of world oceans (Bednarsek et al., 2014; Freely et al., 2008) . Compared to preindustrial, surface oceans have now lost approximately 16% of CO 3 - (Sabine et al., 2004) , which reduced the availability of suitable habitats for bivalve and increased vulnerability of bivalves to stressors (Bednarsek et al., 2014) . The current level of OA in the Pacific Northwest of the United States has resulted in an annual economical loss of $270 million Washington's bivalve aquaculture industry (Washington State Blue Ribbon Panel on Ocean Acidification, 2012). On the other hand, although the impact of OA has not been felt in many places, the OA problem has received considerable attention worldwide. Moreover, regions experiencing seasonal upwelling are particularly vulnerable to OA. Hauri et al. (2013) demonstrated that the early spring equatorial wind caused seasonal upwelling in California Current System (CCS), which led to natural low pH and aragonite saturation in CCS.

Bacterial pathogens have an advantage in climate change induced environments because they are able to adapt to changing environmental conditions faster than their hosts (Williams et al., 2014) . Asplund et al. (2014) and Williams et al. (2014) indicated that ocean acidification may increase the frequency and severity of bivalve disease outbreaks in the marine by increasing marine bacterioplankton communities (Meron et al., 2012) , enhancing pathogen virulence (Zha et al., 2017) , compromising bivalve immunity (Su et al., 2017; Li et al., 2015) , and altering host-pathogen interactions (Asplund et al., 2014) (Table 1) . Alterations of microbial community composition by OA were observed in the Great Barrier Reef (Witt et al., 2011) , Arctic (Tait et al., 2013) , and Antarctica Ocean (Maas et al, 2013) . There are indications that microbial communities of Vibrio population may increase at lower pH values (Meron et al., 2012) due to the wide optimum pH (pH 6.5 to 8.2) of Vibrios growth (Wang and Gu, 2005) . Dorfmeier, (2012) demonstrated that in extreme scenarios of elevated pCO 2 (2000 ppm), the growth and abundance of V. tubiashii in C. gigas larvae were significantly higher than that of ambient pCO 2 levels. Moreover, heterotrophic bacteria tend to produce more proteases (Grossart et al., 2006) and glycosidases (Piontek et al., 2010) at lower pH, where these enzymes play an important role in the degradation of organic compounds, thereby promoting the growth of heterotrophic marine bacteria communities. In addition, higher productions of proteases and glycosidases may also be associated with higher virulence of pathogens (Ridgway et al., 2008) . Laboratory studies revealed that acidic conditions can enhance the virulence of Virio harveyi, and the survival rate and haemolytic activity of V. harveyi were significantly higher in the haemolymph of blood clam, Tegillarca granosa under OA conditions (Zha et al., 2017) . However, the effect of OA on pathogen virulence is highly species-specific, and some V. tubiashii strains have lower pathogenicity to C.

body_text.text: Immunity is energetically costly for the host, in which the energy available for immune responses might reduce if the bivalve is exposed to acidified conditions (Siva-Jothy et al. 2005) . Wang et al. (2016) reported that exposure of Crassostrea gigas to OA (at about 2000 ppm pCO 2 ) for 28 days not only increased apoptosis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in hemocytes, but also reduced the level of some antioxidant enzymes and glutathione in the hemocytes and digestive gland, respectively. It has also been suggested that OA may hamper the immunity of marine bivalves by negatively affecting immune related signaling pathways and limiting the energy allocation for immune responses (Su et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2016) . In the V. parahaemolyticus challenge experiment, the antibacterial capacity in gills of Mytilus edulis that pre-exposed to acidified seawater (pH 7.7) for four months was significantly lower than that that of the control mussels maintained at pH 8.1 (Hernroth et al., 2016) . Similarly, other laboratory studies have also revealed that the antibacterial capacity of My. edulis (Asplund et al., 2013) and T. granosa (Zha et al., 2017; Asplund et al., 2014) were significantly impaired in acidified seawater when challenged with V. tubiashii and V. harveyi, respectively. On the other hand, Matozzo et al. (2012) reported that the effect of OA on the haemocyte functionality in bivalves is species-specific, and Chamelea gallina appear to be more susceptable to OA than My. galloprovincialis (Matozzo et al., 2012) . In addition to lowering the haemocyte functionality, acidified seawater has also been shown to reduce the total haemocyte count and cell type composition of haemocyte in Pinctada fucata (Li et al., 2015) and T. granosa (Su et al., 2017) . As a result, the weakened immunity of bivalves in future climate scenarios may be beneficial for invading bacteria in infecting hosts. In addition, in high densities bivalve farms, bivalves are more vulnerable to OA due to bacteria can easily spread (Tan and Zheng, 2019) .

body_text.text: Bivalves are particularly susceptible to OA because elevated seawater pCO 2 reduces the CaCO 3 saturation of aragonite and calcite (Varag or Vcalc), which negatively affects the calcification and growth of marine bivalves (Kroeker et al., 2010 (Kroeker et al., , 2013 ( Table 2) . Gazeau et al. (2007) and Ries et al. (2009) revealed that the net calcification of blue mussels and scallops reduced by 25% and 10%, respectively, in the case of elevated pCO 2 conditions predicted in 2100. Moreover, embryonic growth of C. gigas (Kurihara et al., 2007) and My. edulis (Gazeau et al., 2010) at pH 7.4 was significantly lower than that in ambient seawater pH, where pH and aragonite saturation state have no effect on embryonic development, but the reduced carbonate ions (CO 3 2-) level was responsible for lower embryonic development (Gazeau et al., 2011 ). Contrary to the findings of other studies, protein expression (Dineshram et al., 2012 ) and metabolism (Lannig et al., 2010) in C. gigas can be depressed at pH < 7.5. Melzner et al. (2011) revealed that acidified seawater introduces additional energy costs and significantly lowered the growth and development of bivalves, particularly in the case of food depletion. On average, Kroeker et al. (2013) estimated that bivalves will reduce calcification and growth rates by 27% and 11%, respectively, in response to the near future acidification scenarios.

The larval stage, particularly during the development of the first shell, called prodissoconch I (PDI), is the most fragile developmental stage of bivalves because of their high energetic costs for organogenesis, rapid calcification rates, and greater exposure of surfaces (total area per unit volume) to the external environment Rumrill, 1990) . Watson et al. (2009) revealed that in acidified seawater (pH 7.8 and 7.6), the survival, growth and development of Saccostrea glomerata larvae were significantly lower than those maintained at ambient water pH, in which S. glomerata larval survival, antero-posterior measurement (APM) and dorso-ventral measurement (DVM) at pH 7.8 and 7.6 decreased by 43% and 72%, 6.3% and 8.7%, and 5.1% and 7.5%, respectively. For C. virginica larvae, Miller et al. (2009) observed that only the growth rate was significantly lowered in acidified seawater, but the effect of OA on survival was relatively small. However, Talmage and Gobler (2009) observed a decreased in the growth rate and survival rate of C. virginica larvae, which had a negative effect on the metamorphosis in response to acidified seawater. Regardless of the species-specific response to OA, all of these studies generally indicate that the growth and survival of bivalve larvae are adversely affected by OA conditions.

Metamorphosis from larvae to juvenile is another critical stage, in which larvae must rely on endogenous energy for the metamorphosis. On the one hand, bivalve larvae tend to have reduced lipid levels under acidification stress, which leads to greater metamorphosis and settlement failure Gobler, 2011, 2010) .

On the other hand, calcification of newly settled juvenile bivalves is more sensitive to acidification, which further increases the mortality rate of newly settle juvenile bivalves (Waldbusser et al., 2010) . Talmage and Gobler (2010) revealed that the freshly settled Mercenaria mercenaria and Argopecten irradians exhibited lower growth and survival rates even at moderately elevated pCO 2 of below 1500 µatm. In addition, Watson et al. (2012) revealed that T. squamosal exhibited <20% survival rate at a relatively lower pCO 2 of 1019 μatm. Similarly, C. gigas larvae that spawned and reared in acidified seawater for the first 48 h demonstrated that the hatching rate and midstage growth rate (120 to 150 mm) of oyster larvae was inversely correlated to the aragonite saturation state of water (Barton et al., 2012) . This can partly explain the recruitment failures of Pacific oysters in Willapa Bay, Washington, for years (Dumbauld et al. 2011) .

It is worth noting that the response of bivalves to pCO 2 rise is species-specific, and some bivalve species show little or no negative response to OA (Walbusser et al., 2016; Beesley et al., 2008; Portner, 2008) . For instance, although the embryonic growth of C. gigas (Kurihara et al., 2007) and My. edulis (Gazeau et al., 2010) appears to be affected by acidified seawater (pH 7.4), but metabolism and tissue condition (Beesley et al., 2008) appear to be unaffected. Interestingly, Walbusser et al. (2016)

Ostrea lurida did not exhibit any negative response to acute ocean acidification treatments. O. lurida is known to have calcification rate and energy consumption rate 10 to 50 times slower than many bivalves, including C. gigas and My. edulis, thereby the slow shell development may lessen the energetic burden under acidification (Walbusser et al., 2016) .

The effects of OA on bivalve shell and byssus are summarized in Table 3 . In general, the effect of OA on bivalve shells varies considerably across species and life stages (Gazeau et al., 2013) . For C. virginica, OA has been shown to reduce shell length and shell thickness in larval individuals (Gobler and Talmage, 2014) and to reduce calcification rates in juveniles (Waldbusser et al., 2011) and adults (Ries et al., 2009) .

body_text.text: In general, Kleypas et al. (2006) predicted that by the end of 2100, the calcification rate of most bivalves could be reduced up to 60%. The rate of shell dissolution is greatest in the larva stage (Weiss et al., 2002) . Watson et al. (2009) recorded a 16% and 90% reduction in the weight of the remaining S. glomerata empty shells from dead larvae at pH 7.8 and pH 7.6, respectively, over 7 days compared to those empty shells maintained at ambient pH. Similar observations have been documented by Waldbusser et al. (2011) , where the dissolution rate of C. virginica empty shells in acidified seawater (pH 7.17 and 7.67) for 2 weeks was significantly higher than that of empty shells maintained at higher pH (pH 7.9). In addition, Waldbusser et al. (2010) demonstrated that the calcification rate of Mercenaria sp. decreased as the water pH decreased, and the smaller post-larval were unable to overcome dissolution pressure.

body_text.text: Tyrosinase plays an important role in the formation of periostracum in mollusc shells (Marin and Luquet, 2004) . Within the tolerance pH range, bivalve larvae can compensate for shell dissolution under acidification conditions by up-regulating tyrosinase gene expression levels (Gehler et al., 2016) . Yang et al. (2017) revealed that C. angulata larvae at the trochophore stage were able to up-regulate tyrosinase gene expression levels to counteract low pH conditions up to 3000 ppm. However, the tyrosinase expression pattern of the larvae is disrupted under acidified conditions, resulting in abnormal shell shape formation (Yang et al., 2017 ).

This explains the observation of much higher dissolution rate of the hard clam (M. mercenaria) shell in the mudflats of coastal Maine (Green et al., 2009) . Green et al. (2013) and Clements and Hunt (2014) observed that settled M. mercenaria and Mya arenaria juveniles tend to avoid burrowing into acidic sediments that are undersaturated with aragonite. Although this action helps to reduce shell dissolution (Green et al., 2009) , but fails to immediately burrow into sediment puts these clams at risk for other mortality factors such as predation, erosion, and burial (Hunt and Scheibling, 1997) . Peng et al. (2017) demonstrated that acidified seawater depressed the metabolism and activity of Ca 2+ / Mg 2+ -ATPase and significantly reduced the digging depth of the Sinonovacula constricta.

body_text.text: Besides that, the inner bivalve shell is more vulnerable to OA than the outer shell, mainly due to the absent of chemically resistant periostracum on the inner shell surface (Melzner et al., 2011) . It has been shown that the pCO 2 in bivalve extrapallial fluid, haemolymph and surrounding water is maintained at the same level to effectively excrete metabolic CO 2 from the cells (Melzner et al., 2009) . Since bivalves cannot regulate the pH of the extrapallial fluid and haemolymph, OA causes more corrosive conditions at the mantle shell interface, thereby increasing the dissolution rate of the inner shell . The integrity of the inner shell surface is influenced by the animals' energy budget. It is likely that under limited food conditions, energy is allocated to more important physiological processes rather than maintaining the integrity of inner shell (Melzner et al., 2011) . Other studies have shown that increased calcification energy demand may not be constrained by available energy, which can be mediated by high food availability (Thomsen et al., 2013; Waldbusser et al., 2010) . Laboratory experiments revealed that the benthic phase of My. edulis is able to tolerate high pCO 2 (up to 3350 µatm) when food supply is abundant (Gazeau et al. 2007) , and the ability to overcome dissolution increases with postlarval size (Waldbusser et al. 2010) . Another study revealed that exposure of adult C. virginica (6-9 cm) to pH 7.5 and 7.0 with abundance food supply for 5 weeks did not affect the morphometric measures (Clements et al., 2017) .

body_text.text: The bivalve byssus is also negatively affected by OA (Zhao et al., 2017; Scanes et al., 2014; O'Donnell et al., 2013) . Zhao et al. (2017) revealed that byssus secretion rate, length and number in thick shell mussel My. coruscus was inversely related to the water pH. Moreover, acidification conditions have also been shown to result in a reduction in the percentage of attached byssal threads in scallop Mimachlamys asperrima (Scanes et al., 2014) , reducing the byssus strength and extensibility in mussels My. trossulus (O'Donnell et al., 2013) and My. coruscus (Zhao et al., 2017) , and reducing the byssus thickness in the pearl oyster P. fucata (Welladsen et al., 2011) . According to mathematical model, when maintained at high pCO2 of >1200 µatm (< pH 7.6), My. trossulus byssal fibre could weakened up to 40% (O'Donnell et al., 2013) . Li et al. (2017) revealed that the decrease in byssus production under OA conditions was mainly due to the up-regulation of apoptosisrelated pathways and down-regulation of the extracellular matrix-receptor interaction pathway leading to changes in foot locomotion physiology of bivalves.

body_text.text: Based on extensive evidence, human activities, especially emissions of greenhouse gases are the major cause of global warming and ocean acidification (Feely et al., 2008) . Therefore, reducing net CO 2 emissions from human activities is the key to limiting near-term climate change and long-term OA. In order to mitigate the effects climate change, international efforts to address this issue have increased since the late 1980s. In 1989, the international Montreal Protocol came into effect and successfully reduced the emission of chloroflurocarbon (CFCs), powerful greenhouse gases, by about 90%. Since then, more and more international efforts have been made to build a comprehensive climate change regime to safer levels (Table 4) (Keohane and Victor, 2011) . Various efforts in cutting down emissions of greenhouse gases have been implemented, including meeting energy demands from clean renewable energy sources (etc switching from coal to solar or wind energy for electricity), increasing energy efficiency, enhancing natural carbon sinks (store carbon in soils and forest), and eliminating the production of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) (Harris et al., 2017) . As the result, as economic growth became less carbon-intensive, emission growth rates have slowed since 2014 (Harris et al., 2017) . Therefore, it is reasonable to believe that increasing individual, national and international awareness and efforts in fighting climate change could slow the pace of climate change.

Long term exposure to persistent environmental changes can either lead to acclimation or worsening of vulnerability, depending on whether the change is within tolerance, thereby enhancing population growth or extinction (IPCC, 2014). Frieder et al. (2017) revealed that although bivalve larvae exposed to acidified seawater exhibit some negative effects (shell mass is reduced by 56% and dissolution increased at aragonite undersaturation), the first-shell formation is not subject to energy limitation due to there are sufficient endogenous reserves available to meet metabolic needs.

Since the rate of change in OA is within the tolerance of bivalves, the key question is how quickly bivalves can compensate for the negative effects of OA, either by shortterm acclimatization or long-term evolutionary adaptation over generations (Peijnenburg and Goetze, 2013) . Frieder et al. (2017) studied the response of bivalve larvae from pure genetic crosses to acidified seawater. The results showed that the bivalve larvae responded differently to OA, from no effect to a 28% reduction in shell length, confirming the existence of resilience to ocean acidification among genotypes.

Thus, at current OA rates, repeated exposure of sublethal stressful conditions to many bivalve species to can lead to transgenerational acclimation and increased tolerance to the future extremes (Stillman, 2003) . At the same time, offspring may exhibit reduced sensitivity to stressors, especially in the early life stages (Salinas and Munch, 2012) .

In this regard, Watson et al. (2012) revealed that if we can slow the rate of ocean acidification, species may be able to gradually adapt to changing conditions. Therefore, if continuous efforts to address climate change can slow the pace of OA, then bivalve aquaculture does not require any adjustments.
Coastal waters are affected by many sources of CO 2 and acid input from the surrounding watersheds, which may amplify the OA effects (Duarte et al., 2013) .

Moreover, the high rate of microbial respiration and decomposition of organic matter in coastal waters not only amplifies low pH conditions, but is often associated with low dissolved oxygen . Therefore, coastal waters, particularly the estuary, have experienced more acidic conditions than well-buffered open oceans (Waldbusser and Salisbury, 2014; Duarte et al., 2013) . This phenomenon has been reported by Mucci et al. (2010) , where acidification of the waters of the Northwest Atlantic coast was amplified by local anthropogenic activities along the coast of New Brunswick (Ekstrom et al., 2015) . In fact, the Whiskey Creek Shellfish Hatchery in Oregon experienced a direct impact of enhanced ocean acidification, and it was reported that the mass mortality of oyster larvae from to 2008 was due to the extremely low carbonate saturation in seawater (Barton et al., 2012) .

Moreover, the coastal environment is affected by upwelling events, and deep water rich in pCO 2 can be brought from deep to nearshore surface through physical processes, resulting in elevated pCO 2 levels in coastal waters. Feely et al. (2008) documented that the upwelling of the Pacific coast of central North America bought high levels of pCO 2 to coastal waters, resulting in a significant increase in the corrosiveness of coastal waters. As a result, coastal upwelling driven acidified water has caused severe losses to shellfish hatcheries in certain parts of the Pacific coast, including Washington State, USA (Taylor Shellfish, Quilcene; water from Hood Canal) and British Columbia, Canada (Island Scallops, Nanaimo; water from Qualicum Bay) (Barton et al., 2012 ).

On the other hand, seawater systems in high latitudes usually have a lower buffering capacity for buffering acidity changes, so seasonal corrosion conditions are more common and frequent in high-latitudes systems than in low-latitude systems (Lough and Hobday, 2011) . Long term pH declines over the past century have been documented on the Northwest Atlantic shelf (Thornalley et al., 2018; Levin, 2018;  circulations, the Gulf Stream and the Labrador Current, which transports CO 2 rich tropical and subtropical water masses to the north and well-oxygenated water masses to the south, respectively (Sherwood et al., 2011) . In addition, there is evidence that climate change can trigger Vibro risk at high latitudes (Baker-Austin et al., 2012) .
Therefore, all these observations suggest moving bivalve aquaculture farms seaward, southward and away from organic pollutants to avoid amplification of the OA effects.

It is also important to note that the food availability for bivalves in open waters would be lower. Therefore, the site suitability and the carrying capacity for bivalve farming should be carefully evaluated to ensure the sustainability of bivalve farming in certain areas.

Integrated multitrophic aquaculture (IMTA) is an intensive and synergistic approach to aquaculture involving various species from different trophic levels with complementary ecosystem functions, in which the water-borne nutrient (wastes and by-products) from one species serve as the food source of one or a number of other species (Chopin, 2013) . At a local scale, the IMTA can be an adaptive strategy for OA, where seaweed or seagrass are key components that reduce the effects of OA by absorbing and assimilating dissolved CO 2 from surrounding water (Chopin, 2015) . Semesi et al. (2009) revealed that the high photosynthetic rate of tropical seagrass meadows increased the seawater pH from 7.9 to 8.9, which was positively associated with the calcification rate of Hydrolithon sp. It is worth noting that IMTA can be applied not only to marine environment, but also to the hatchery system, in which the incoming seawater is first treated (buffer low pH seawater) with macroalgae or microalgae and then supplied to the shellfish tanks. As the result, IMTA can effectively reduce the impact of OA in bivalve farms, and farmed bivalves can gradually acclimate/adapt to changes in carbonate chemistry. Hence, the role of IMTA in mitigating the impact of future ocean acidification on coastal bivalve farms and shellfish hatcheries is worthy of attention.

Species with shorter generational (i.e. weeks to months) times may have better ability to adapt to OA than those organisms with much longer generational times (i.e. years) (Miller et al., 2009) . This is because beneficial phenotypic changes are unlikely to occur in only a single generation, with laboratory studies have shown that there was no transgenerational acclimation to OA for M. mercenaria and A. irradians over a single generation (Griffith and Gobler, 2017) . In fact, exposure of parental bivalves to OA does not always enhance the resistance of offspring. In some cases, it may have negative carryover effects and make the subsequent generations even more sensitive to OA (Schade et al., 2014; Byrne, 2011) . Offspring of OA treatment M. mercenaria and A. irradians adults are more vulnerable to acidification and other stressors than offspring originating from adults conditioned under ambient pCO 2 (Griffith and Gobler, 2017) . In nature, this negative carryover effects may persist for generations in the presence of persistent stress until beneficial mutations and/or natural selection for individuals that are better adapted to such environments (Sultan, 2007) . Since climate change is associated with multiple stressors, this synergistic effects may have a more severe impact on bivalves (Doney et al., 2012) , thereby, bivalves with long generational (i.e. years) times may not stand a chance to acclimate or adapt to the future ocean conditions induced by climate change. Therefore, for bivalves with long generation times, particularly giant clams, genetic breeding research is urgently needed to accelerate the transgenerational acclimation and prepare them to the future changing ocean conditions.

Genetic breeding can be used as an adaptive tool to enhance the resilience traits of aquaculture candidates to better adapt to climate change. For example , Parker et al. (2012) demonstrated that the selective breeding of Sydney rock oyster S. glomerata significantly reduced the negative effect of ocean acidification on the growth of S. glomerata shells, where the selective breeding population elicited a much lower reduction in shell growth compare to wild populations at pH 7.7 (25% versus 64% for selectively bred and wild population, respectively). Moreover, S. glomerata larvae derived from parents conditioned under acidified conditions (pH = 7.7; pCO 2 = 856 μatm), exhibited faster growth and development than larvae derived from parents conditioning in ambient pH regime (Parker et al., 2012) . Similarly, Thomsen et al. (2017) observed that My. edulis larvae derived from environments naturally enriched in CO 2 have a greater adaptability and increased fitness when grown in an acidified environments than larvae originating from non CO -enriched environments. In the noble scallop Chlamys nobilis the new variety of noble scallop (named Nan'ao Golden Scallop) produce from genetic breeding is more adaptable to various stressors than common noble scallops by up-regulating several immune-related genes including
Thioredoxins (Zhang et al., 2018) , Toll-like receptors (Lu et al., 2016) , Vitellogenin (Vg) (Zhang et al., 2016) and CuZnSOD (Han et al., 2016 ) by 1.18 to 1.76 times.

Moreover, the Nan'ao Golden Scallop are naturally rich in carotenoids (Zheng et al., 2010) , which is an important component of cellular self-defense that helps neutralize excessive reactive oxygen species. demonstrated that exposure to acidic conditions increases the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), a byproduct of the respiratory process that has significant extracellular and intracellular damage. Therefore, high total carotenoid content can further improve the immunity and environmental tolerance of Nan'ao Golden Scallops. It is reasonable to believe that genetic breeding is a promising approach (could be the key solution) for future bivalve aquaculture to improve the climate change resilience.

In the world of aquaculture, changes in marine environmental conditions caused by anthropogenic climate change have become a prime issue and have received considerable attention. There is growing evidence from laboratory experiments and time series observations that the additive stressors of ocean acidification and global warming are particularly problematic for marine life. Acidification has been shown to negatively affect the recruitment, development (Parker et al., 2009) , growth and survival (Tan and Zheng, 2019; of marine bivalves. Shi et al. (2017ab) observed that OA significantly reduce the fertilization rate of T. granos games by reducing the sperm motility. The calcification process of bivalve is strongly influence by the water pH (Gazeau et al., 2013; Waldbusser et al., 2013) .

Consequently, for many bivalve species, shell growth and integrity are compromised (Dorfmeier 2012) , and increased vulnerability to diseases and parasites under more acidic conditions, resulting in higher levels of mortality (Barton et al., 2012; Green et al., 2013) . Since the effects of OA on shell growth and development are also associated with water temperature and other parameters, there are potential synergies among multiple environmental changes associated with climate change, where the combined effects of two or more drivers on species may be worse than the additive influence of the individual factors (Tan and Zheng, 2019; Brook et al., 2008) .

However, some studies have shown that the presence of a second driver may reduce the impact of another stressor (Crain et al., 2008) . Kroeker et al. (2014) reported that warming can reduce the effects of OA on bivalves by altering the physiology of bivalves and seawater geochemistry, with the negative impact of OA (1200 µatm CO 2 ) on My. galloprovincialis growth is gradually lessened with successive warming from 14 to 20 ˚C. Furthermore, warmer conditions stimulate the growth of bivalve shells, which is independent of CO 2 treatment (Brook et al., 2008) . Caution though, it is worth noting that most of the above mentioned effects of climate change on cultured shellfish are derived from laboratory experiments. Many studies are short term and use acute exposure. It may not reflect how bivalves are exposed in an OA environment. Therefore, more chronic exposure experiments or field observations are required to provide a more accurate prediction of the fate of bivalves in the future ocean.

In the footsteps of global warming, on the one hand, alterations of seawater salinity have attracted considerable attention, mainly in the estuary and coastal areas (Kay et al., 2006) . Global warming is associated to changes in the global hydrological cycle, where precipitation in high latitudes and tropical regions may be higher, while precipitation in subtropical and mid-latitude regions is reduced, thereby drought or flooding will occur in many areas (Fenoglio et al., 2010) . In the estuaries where frequent flood events occur, prolonged and more frequent periods of reduced salinity are expected (Bussell et al., 2008) . On the other hand, it is widely believed that the dissolved oxygen (O 2 ) concentrations in the global ocean decline as the seawater temperature increase (Long et al, 2016) . Deoxygenation rate vary from region to region, and the northwest Atlantic coastal waters has shown long-term deoxygenation trends over the past century (Brennan et al., 2016; Gilbert et al., 2005) far exceeding the average deoxygenation rate in the global and North Atlantic basin (Levin, 2018) .

Palaeoceanographic records of the past millennium documented warming, salinification and changing nutrient supply on the Scotian Shelf during the past century (Thornalley et al., 2018) , where these coastal changes may reflect variations in large-scale offshore circulation that transports well-oxygenated water masses to the south (Labrador Current) and oxygen-deficient water masses from tropical and subtropical to northern regions, (Sherwood et al., 2011) . Therefore, in order to mitigate the negative effects of climate change, bivalve aquaculture should relocate to seaward and southwards in the near future.

Chronic exposure to ocean changing conditions is believed to trigger animals' acclimatization to the environment, which enhance individual physiological tolerance traits or diminishing sensitivity (IPCC, 2014) . Integrated multi-trophic aquaculture (IMTA) approach is indeed relevant to all bivalve species in all regions, as it helps mitigate the effects of climate change and allows the bivalves to gradually adapt to slower ocean changing conditions. With the help of IMTA, small sizes bivalve species with shorter generation times may have promising capacity for transgenerational acclimation to changing ocean pCO2 (Miller et al., 2009) . However, for some bivalve species with long maturity time and generational periods, especially giant clams, the ability to acclimation and adaptation in the next 100 years may be reduced. Therefore, in addition to the IMTA approach, artificial genetic breeding for these bivalves is needed to speed up the evolution process and enhance climate resilience (Figure 2 ).

Genetic breeding approaches have many successful examples in bivalve aquaculture (Zhang et al., 2018; Thomsen et al., 2017; Han et al., 2016; Parker et al., 2012) , therefore, comprehensive studies of bioenergetics and genetics is promising to understand the effects of climate change on marine bivalves. Other important areas of future genetic breeding research include reducing metabolic rate and increasing the tolerance of bivalves to low dissolved oxygen (DO) conditions. It has been reported that by reducing the energetic burden of acidification, slow shell building and decreased metabolism rate are one of the effective ways of bivalve tolerance to OA (Walbusser et al., 2016) . On the other hand, Schmidtko et al. (2017) revealed that in the past five decades, the ocean has loss approximately 2% of dissolved oxygen.

Therefore, bivalves with lower metabolism and lower oxygen consumption rate have the advantage of better adapting the near future low DO environment. More studies are highly recommended to identify other climate change resilience traits to facilitate transgenerational acclimation or evolution of aquaculture important mollusc species to tolerate the changing ocean conditions. In addition, it is also interesting to compare the impacts of OA on bivalve farming in temperate and tropical waters, or between coastal (low buffer capacity) and open water (high buffer capacity).

In conclusion, multiple lines of scientific evidence revealed that OA have deleterious effects on the growth and development of marine bivalves. Switching cultivation sides and adopting an integrated multi-trophic aquaculture (IMTA) approach can be a good temporally approaches for mitigating the effects of climate change and providing longer time to adapt to changing ocean conditions by transgenerational acclimation.

However, for some areas that have experienced intense climate change effects or some bivalve species that have long generational time, IMTA alone may not be sufficient to address climate change issues. Our results emphasize the need for genetic breeding as a long term approach to accelerate transgenerational acclimation or artificial evolution to improve the climate resilience of bivalves.
